unnormalised: AI is all the buzz these days, isn't it? Just saw a report saying IIT Delhi is launching a new course on AI ethics. It's a big deal, especially with all the concerns about bias in algorithms. Apparently, the course starts on 15/07/2024.
normalised: A-I is all the buzz these days, isn't it? Just saw a report saying I-I-T Delhi is launching a new course on A-I ethics. It's a big deal, especially with all the concerns about bias in algorithms. Apparently, the course starts on fifteenth July two thousand and twenty four.

unnormalised: Also, rumour has it that TCS is developing a new AI-powered customer service platform, aiming for a launch by Q4 2023. They're calling it "Project Aaina", pretty cool name, eh? Supposedly, it'll handle 80% of customer queries automatically, saving the company big bucks.
normalised: Also, rumour has it that T-C-S is developing a new A-I-powered customer service platform, aiming for a launch by Q four two thousand and twenty three. They're calling it "Project Aaina", pretty cool name, eh? Supposedly, it'll handle eighty percent of customer queries automatically, saving the company big bucks.

unnormalised: Google's been making waves too. Their new AI model, they're calling it something like "Gyan", beat the Turing test. Pretty crazy stuff. This happened like last week. It scored something like 9.2 out of 10. And its all based on the 3.5 billion paramter architecture that Google is using.
normalised: Google's been making waves too. Their new A-I model, they're calling it something like "Gyan", beat the Turing test. Pretty crazy stuff. This happened like last week. It scored something like nine point two out of ten. And its all based on the three point five billion parameter architecture that Google is using.

unnormalised: And get this, a startup in Bangalore, called "InnovAIte," just secured $2 million in seed funding for their AI-based farming tech. Their system apparently boosts crop yield by 20%, using AI to predict weather patterns and soil conditions. Farmers in the Vidarbha region are already seeing benefits, so they are saying.
normalised: And get this, a startup in Bangalore, called "InnovA-Ite," just secured dollar two million in seed funding for their A-I-based farming tech. Their system apparently boosts crop yield by twenty percent, using A-I to predict weather patterns and soil conditions. Farmers in the Vidarbha region are already seeing benefits, so they are saying.

unnormalised: So, yeah, AI's basically everywhere, from IIT classrooms to Bangalore farms. And it’s only gonna get bigger, no? Can't wait to see what crazy new stuff comes out next.
normalised: So, yeah, A-I's basically everywhere, from I-I-T classrooms to Bangalore farms. And it’s only gonna get bigger, no? Can't wait to see what crazy new stuff comes out next.
